trial_identification.studytitle: Internet versus face to face cognitive behaviour therapy for social phobia
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In patients seeking treatment for social phobia internet cognitive behaviour therapy will be compared with face to face cognitive behaviour therapy on the reduction in social phobia scores.

interventions.interventions: Cognitive behaviour therapy delivered by the internet Six sessions/lessons of less than 50 minutes on a 7-10 day schedule following the content outlined in Andrews et al Treatment of Anxiety Disorders, Cambridge University Press, 2003. (Psychoeducation, dearousal strategies, cognitive therapy, graded exposure).
interventions.comparator: Cognitive behaviour therapy delivered in the clinic on a face to face basis. Six sessions/lessons of less than 50 minutes on a 7-10 day schedule following the content outlined in Andrews et al Treatment of Anxiety Disorders, Cambridge University Press, 2003.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Reduction in social phobia as demonstrated from scores on Social Interaction Anxiety Scale (SIAS) and Social Phobia Scale (SPS)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Reduction in comorbid depression and anxiety as demonstrated from changes in the PHQ-9 and GAD-7

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: accepted for treatment for social phobia at the St Vincent's Anxiety Disorders Clinic
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Intake clinicians at the clinic do not offer treatment to people with comorbid psychosis, substance use disorder or severe personality disorder.

trial_design.concealment: Subjects selected for treatment for social phobia at the clinic who have an email address and internet access will be invited to participate in the trial. They will know that have a 1 in 2 chance of being allocated to one of the treatment arms, internet CBT or face to face CBT. Allocation involved contacting the holder of the allocation schedule who was at central administration site.
trial_design.sequence: Computerised sequence generation using a web-based tool at www.random.org

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: St Vincent's Hospital, 390 Victoria St, Darlinghurst, Sydney, NSW, 2010

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Cumberland Hospital, Fleet St, North Paramatta, NSW, 2151.

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: Cumberland Hospital, Fleet St, North Paramatta, NSW, 2151

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Cognitive behaviour therapy delivered either face to face or over the web has been shown to be an effective treatment for social phobia. It is not known whether people referrred for face to face treatment will benefit from internet therapy This trial will determine that.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Andrews G, Davis M, Titov N: Effectiveness randomized controlled trial of face to face versus Internet cognitive behaviour therapy for social phobia. Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry. 2011, 45(4): 337-340.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: St Vincent's Hospital Human Research Ethics Committee
